keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former January 6 Capitol riot participant, was arrested on a charge of threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously sentenced to nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct during the Capitol attack.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier this year as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants, which drew criticism from Hakeem Jeffries.
Jeffries called the pardon 'blanket' and emphasized that threats of violence will not deter democratic participation.
Moynihan allegedly threatened to kill Jeffries in a text message, stating he would eliminate him 'for the future' and 'even if he is hated he must be eliminated'.
The New York judge ruled Moynihan will remain in prison while awaiting a hearing on release pending trial, with no legal representation listed.
Law enforcement cited concerns over Moynihan's recent drug abuse and increased homicidal ideations, indicating potential mental health and substance use risks.
Prior to the Capitol riot, Moynihan had been struggling with opiate addiction and misdemeanor convictions linked to substance use.
Moynihan's attorneys noted he became politically active during the Trump presidency and spent time consuming political content online.
This case reflects heightened national concern over threats against public officials, especially after recent assassinations such as that of Charlie Kirk.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man convicted of participating in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested on a charge of threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan had previously been sentenced to nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier this year, he was re-arrested after allegedly sending texts threatening to kill Jeffries in New York City, stating he would eliminate him 'for the future.' The threat comes amid rising national concern over political violence, especially after the recent assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk. Authorities have expressed concern about Moynihan's drug use and homicidal ideations, and a New York judge has ordered him to remain in prison pending a hearing on release. The case highlights tensions between executive clemency and public safety, as well as the ongoing threat of violence against elected officials.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
